reviewText: It was great! great condition and it arrived right on time! very happy with this purchase!

I love Roy Rogers & Dale Evans! Before everything had to be "cutting edge"! Well, I for one and sick of bleeding! No gore, no sex, no swearing! I can watch these with the family - not much of that left on the air these days! THANK-YOU AMAZON for making theses available! There's a good story, great music and TRIGGER, THE SMARTEST HORSE IN THE MOVIES! YIPPI KI YAY!!!!
Couldn't watch it . it kept stopping every 2 min to reload unbelievable.

I ordered this DVD thinking that Desert Island Films produced quality film ............ boy was I wrong.  Not only was the run time listed incorrectly (it is approximately 54") but is listed as 78".  The quality of the video is also terrible.  BETTER PASS THIS ONE BY!
Was hopeful to see a good old fashioned black and white cowboy movie--was disappointed. Slow moving plot and corny verbiage, and singing that made no sense, with supposed enemies.

Cowboy and the Senorita, 1944 film

The story begins with music and singing at a restaurant. An angry customer complains, two workers are fired and ride away. The sheriff and posse are looking for a lost girl. Roy and Teddy Bear are suspected of kidnapping this lost girl. The escape in a comic routine. Men ride after them. Chip shows up for a meal, and explains why she ran away. She wants to keep her father's old gold mine. Roy and Teddy Bear get a new job working for Isabella. Chip and Ray talk about the box said to be in that old mine. Why does Craig Allen want to buy a worthless gold mine? There is a song. They explore the mine, Chip finds a letter in the hidden box. "Just a bracelet?" Roy and Teddy Bear take a short cut to town, but have to run away when an alarm goes off.

The posse catches them, but they explain their suspicions about Allen. The posse goes along to inspect Chip's mine, and finds a hidden tunnel with valuable ore. Can Roy and the men bring the valuable ore into town to prevent the sale? The posse pursues them. There is a chase for action. "They went that-away." The assay office says its "$800 a ton ore". Chip's fortune is saved. Is this fraud or misrepresentation? Ferguson confesses about the frame-up. The sheriff will take charge of the two men. There is a celebration with dancers, then a song about "enchiladas". Another dance and song for the usual happy ending.

This is certainly different from most other Roy Rogers' movies. Its like a dude ranch compared to a working ranch. There is a prominent man in town who turns out to be crooked, there are false charges against the heroes who have to redeem themselves. While below average, but still viewable. Note how Craig's contract says they will share the "profits". Craig knew his production company could raise costs to siphon off the profits. And it would be perfectly legal.

Republic Pictures presents "COWBOY AND THE SENORITA" (12 May 1944) (78 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) --- Roy Rogers (born Leonard Slye) moved to California in 1930, at the age of 18 --- played in such musical groups as The Hollywood Hillbillies, Rocky Mountaineers, Texas Outlaws and his own group, the International Cowboys --- In 1934 he formed a group with Bob Nolan and Tim Spencer called "Sons of the Pioneers" --- While in that group he was known as Leonard Slye, then Dick Weston and finally Roy Rogers --- Their songs included "Cool Water" and "Tumbling Tumbleweeds" --- They first appeared in the western "Rhythm on the Range" (1936), starring Bing Crosby --- In 1937 Roy went solo and made his first starring film in 1938, "Under Western Stars" (1938) --- He made almost 100 films --- then came television, "The Roy Rogers Show" (1951) ran on CBS from October 1951 through September 1964.

Under the production staff of:
Joseph Kane (Director)
Harry Grey (Producer)
Gordon Kahn (Screenwriter)
Bradford Ropes (Short Story Author)
Reggie Lanning (Cinematographer)
Phil Ohman (Composer (Music Score)
Walter Scharf (Musical Direction/Supervision / Composer (Music Score)
Ned Washington (Composer (Music Score)
Tony Martinelli (Editor)
Fred A. Ritter (Production Designer)
Charles Thompson (Set Designer)
Larry Ceballos (Choreography)

Our story line and plot, Dale Evans makes her first appearance with Roy Rogers --- Roy helps a teenage girl maintain ownership of a rich gold mine left by her deceased father --- Dale plays a Mexican ranch owner who is caring for the teenager --- Roy and Dale demonstrate their combined musical talent in a final production number, with the help of Mary Lee and the Sons of the Pioneers, and such guest artists as the dance team of Jane Beebe and Ben Rochelle --- don't miss Trigger as the center of things as prescribed by his co-star billing --- The film title is also the name of the opening and closing musical number, and even if not meant to be prophetic, the eventual marriage of Roy Rogers and Dale Evans proved to be a wonderful union for filmgoers and fans of the Western duo --- some wonderful tunes, COWBOY AND THE SENORITA -- WHAT'LL I USE FOR MONEY -- THE ENCHILADA MAN -- BUNK HOUSE BUGLE BOY -- SHE WORE A YELLOW RIBBON -- BESAME MUCHO.

2. Dale Evans (aka: Frances Octavia Smith)
Date of Birth: 31 October 1912, Uvalde, Texas
Date of Death: 7 February 2001, Apple Valley, California

Ask Amazon. Com to carry the above titles as many are not available on Amazon as of yet...you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment...if you enjoyed this collection, why not pick up other copies of Roy Rogers Double Features.

Check out a new book from Empire Publishing - "THE ROY ROGERS BOOK: A REFERENCE TRIVIA SCRAPBOOK" (Paperback) --- reference trivia scrapbook of Roy Rogers written by Western film historian David Rothel whose accounts of thrilling adventures of B-Western heroes during the Saturday matinees of yesteryear takes us back to our childhood, family and friends --- this is a wish come true, reliving those wonderful years from the past through the pen of David Rothel --- Roy was a top box office draw for Republic Pictures when you went to see him on the big screen, you got exactly what the marquee said --- plenty of thrills, action and hard riding with a song or two thrown in for good measure --- Elected to the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1980 as a member of the "Sons of the Pioneers" and elected again in 1988 as Roy Rogers "King of the Cowboys" --- Roy got his horse "Trigger" in 1938 and rode him in every one of his films and TV shows after that --- "Trigger" died in 1965 age of thirty-three --- Roy's dog's name was "Bullet" and appeared in almost as many of his films as "Trigger" did --- Roy's theme song, "Happy Trails", was written by Queen of the West and his wife Dale Evans --- inducted (with his wife Dale Evans) into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1976 --- inducted as a member of the "Sons of the Pioneers into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1995 just three years before his death --- Don't miss this one --- now appearing on Amazon and Empire Publishing --- Don't hesitate - rush out and pick up your copy today --- Great reading in the days and weeks to come --- I guarantee it!

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc), Buck Rainey (The Life & Films of Buck Jones) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- If you're into the memories of B-Westerns with high drama, this is the one you've been anxiously waiting for --- please stand up and take a bow Western Classics --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 78 min on DVD ~ Republic Pictures ~ (10/14/2007)

After watching the not so good Apache Rose I was confused about Roy Rogers' following. This movie has made it clear to me. This was Dale Evans first time with Roy in a film. But she's more of a supporting character. The main female star in this movie is Mary Lee which was all right with me. Mary was a spunky teenager with a beautiful voice. She looks so pretty here and steals the show. The plot Roy Rogers and his friend help Mary find some gold that her dead uncle hid. For a while Dale is even a villian!
Great old time movies,  enjoyed Roy again.  Thanks
A GOOD OLD FASHIONED SIMPLE MOVIE.
Will watch any of Roy's Cowboys good clean movies hard to find now days.

Another great RR "mini-movie." Production values are good, considering when and what it is ('C' movie.') The story was typical for RR and the entire thing seems to have been filmed in San Bernadino County, east of Los Angeles, as do his other films. I'd bet it took less than 2 weeks to shoot the entire movie, as they use lots of 'B' roll for the scenery and horses galloping down roads. Just typical RR.

Dale Evans get's second billing in this show; which makes sense, because she and Roger's didn't get married until 1946 and this movie was made in 1944. Still, it was disappointing to see her take second.

Originally "Trigger" was a studio horse named "Golden Cloud." (Olivia DeHaviland rode Trigger in the 1932 version of "Robin Hood," but he is only seen in one scenethe one filmed next to Chico Creek, in Lower Bidwell Park, Chico, CA, where most of the outdoor photography was done.) Roger's bought him from the studio in 1943. In the movies made after 1943, "Trigger's" tack was plain leather, about what the other studio horses used. Gradually, silver tack was acquired to adorn him. (In the end, some of his saddles weighed up to 150lbs, that's a lot of burden on the horse.) It is noticeable in this movie, "Trigger's" tack is plain leather and he looks much worse for it.

All-in-all, another great Roy Roger's movie!
Its a fair story, but it fun to watch Dale Evans and Roy Rogers before they were a couple.  There was chemistry between them.
Wonderful singing. Fun story. Watch and enjoy.

This is a simple, yet charming Western featuring the famous cowboy couple, Roy Rogers and Dale Evans.  Roy Rogers sings especially beautifully in this film.  And his hefty sidekick, teddy bear, is a likeable sort, too.  The plot is predictable from the outset, yet it is well executed by all the actors in the film, so it makes for a fun, clean, evening at home to watch this movie.  One of the highlights of the motion picture is the spunkiness of the young girl, Chip.  As the underage heiress to a mine that her father claims to have hid a treasure in, she runs away in an attempt to find it before her older half-sister sells it to the big man in town who already owns everything.  Roy Rogers and his sidekick in the process get accused of having kidnapped the young girl so they end up helping Chip in an aim to set the record straight.  For light-hearted and clean fun, this movie is just the perfect fare.
Roy Rogers and Dale Evans are my all time heroes!
